content:
Very nice puzzle. I have made various modifications to the statement to improve readability and grammar. Please read it over again to make sure that it looks correct.

I have solved the puzzle and have voted to approve it.

Thank you for the fun problem.
The empty line is useless.

Ok, getting there.

Pre-solve comments:

* relations seem to be between any two features, including name. So why is the name made special by being reduced to an initial? (when the tests don't even need that)

* I don't see Einstein's actual riddle in the test cases. It should really be there.

* I'd suggest using a clue format that's easy to parse in all languages (i.e., space-separated). For example: "George - Salad" and "George | Salad"

* it's been a long time, but I recall part of the original riddle was to extract all features from the hints, which is out of the picture here. Is that voluntary? Can we root to get it back?

* I don't think 1*2 is very interesting, and I do think it's a naughty surprise to present as a pendant for 2*1.

* "an Einstein's riddle" sounds like a grammatical error, yet it's kinda cute. I'd keep it anyway ^^
Good puzzle, suitable for codingame. One remark about the specifications : you should say that every list of different possible characteristics has size nbPeople.

I added a paragraph about possibilities of each characteristic for that purpose.
Thanks for the feedback

Thanks for your feedback, much appreciated!

* For the clue format, I formerly had "G & Salad" and "G ! Salad", but I put a very hard riddle that was too long for the input (no more characters available), so I removed the spaces (to be shorter). But finally, I thought the last one was too hard and I removed it. So now that it can fit the available number of characters, I think I can revert back to "G ! Salad" format. 

* As for Einstein's real riddle, it's a bit different from what I present here, as there is an actual order of people (G lives in the next house to the right, for example), and I am not sure how this can fit with my format as it is now.

* Well, for the names,... I don't know, it was actually to simplify my inputs (manual input is long) AND to shorten it, but I guess I could do a find/replace now

* Extract all features from the hints? What do you mean exactly? Guess from some sentences the features? Guess all characteristics from the hints without actually describing them?

* I wanted to do a 1 * x or x * 1 test for an obvious test, just as a control sample

* Do you mean we don't put a pronoun before a proper name? English is not my first language... do you really think I should keep it ? ^^

I'll do these changes later, as I am kinda exhausted right now.

I changed the input to be
C P / C lines of P words / N / N lines of relations
without any blank line, as suggested by JBM
Thanks for the improvements and the vote!

Mid-solve comments:

* I've looked up the canonical one online in the meantime. Indeed, it doesn't fit your format. It would actually have much stronger on both parsing and unification. Which could make for a great puzzle as well, but a different (and harder) one.

* for the names, yeah, I think it's more clear for at least the part of them that's used as examples and in the problem statement. You can do whatever makes sense to push the boundaries in the later (say 3rd and on) test cases if you need to squeeze more attributes in there.

* extract features from the hints means mostly "not have an enumeration of features at all". But I mostly wrote this with the canonical riddle in mind, I think your puzzle is actually fine in this regard.

* I'm fine with control tests in theory, though in your puzzle's case I think they'd be better spent exploring weirder logic cases (but that's just weak opinion, nothing to act upon per se). What really bugs me is the fact the validation case checks something different to the test case. But your tests do have sensible titles, it might be ok after all.

* The saxon genitive is worth a "the" determiner. (so if you wanted an "a", you'd hack with something like "one of Einstein's riddles"). But there isn't a commonly accepted single noun for this puzzle type, so I think adding an "an" elevates it to the rank of common noun in a grammatically incorrect yet humorous way. That I personally find tasteful here. YMMV.

I'm kind of exhausted too. Must be your puzzle :p

Updated :

* The names are now full firstname
* Now the relational links are space separated
* The solution (to read the updated links)

Next :
* Maybe another test case more complex... 

Does our solution have to solve all the most complex test cases or... ?
My problem is:
I think my solution solves all medium and medium/hard puzzles (all those in the test cases for now), but not much harder, and I'd like to permit more advanced solutions to more complex puzzles to be posted

AFAIC you can do what you want with your solution, I'm not reading it before I solved it independently, possibly ever.

About harder cases, well, you'd have to be sure they're actually well-formed, or we'd have bigger issues down the road. And as usual, the limiting factor is probably going to be the input size limitation.
(and you wouldn't want to submit a puzzle even you wouldn't be able to solve, would you?)

My suggestion would be to leave it as an open problem for the approvers if they're motivated enough. If they are and come up with faster solutions, we can discuss it. If not and the puzzle passes anyway, that'll be up for grabs when someone packages the complete version of the puzzle.

Near-end-of-solve comments:

* My solver finds no solution at all for both 7*6 cases. I'll have to dig deeper to compare to yours.

* Input format: despite being aware of it, nicola's remark bit me. My two alternate suggestions would be to either:
  * C P / C lines of P words / N / N lines of relations
or
  * C P N / C lines of P words / N lines of relations
No blank line in any case

* My code's a real mess, I'll have to restructure it a lot to go towards a saner structure to maintain state.
* But no apparent performance problems at all considering the input size.

* I forgot what I was going to put here. It's late.

If you have a larger test case you want to send me, I'd be happy to try it in my solution. I haven't really done anything to optimize yet and it doesn't timeout on the current set.

I'm not motivated to try to devise my own test case, though. :-)

After thinking about it some more, I have decided that I agree with @JBM's assertion that a 1 * 2 introduced in a validator is probably not wise.

Since you seem to be keen on keeping the testcases, and I'm not opposed to it, I have broken them out into two separate test / validator pairs: one pair of 2 * 1 tests, and one pair of 1 * 2. Hopefully this doesn't ruffle any feathers.

I'm not 100% sure, as my solution is not deep enough for this, but here is another input/output :
================

Do you think I should add it ?

Post-solve comments: (found fixed my stupid index inversion bug)

* Thank you for the input format update :-D

* I'm fine because I knew the problem beforehand, but I still think the wording can get a bit confusing between characteristics, categories, possibilities and forward referencing to the example. I'll try and think of something.

* I solved your 8*7 puzzle and found the same output. But it took 52 seconds (at home), so it's not CG-worthy yet. My algorithm is optimizable, but not in asymptotic complexity, so I *could* try the other approach I had in mind, but am not convinced yet such a test would be reasonable.

* [I had an open question about the relevance of numbers used as characteristics, but decided it didn't really matter since we never get to sort on it]

> am not convinced yet such a test would be reasonable

I'm not so sure, though it might not be. My own solution solves the 8 * 7 in 2700 ms on my PC. That's a far cry from where it needs to be, but at the same time I know that my algorithm is not as efficient as it could be. I do a lot of extra loops and unnecessary comparisons, favoring code organization over speed. Maybe I'll try to optimize later to see if I can get it there.
I'll do the massive rehaul now (the one I wouldn't publish my code without), that'll avoid a lot of undue consing and could be dramatic. Then we talk ^^
I just made a small refactoring to avoid closures and use a HashSet instead of a list search to avoid duplicating logic, and I'm now down to 239 ms for the 8*7 on my PC, and it passes in CG.
But can it pass with a scripting language? O:-)
40s operating on ints instead of strings; 14s using a dedicated IntSet instead of a generic one. This is getting somewhere.
Bit of a moot point now, since this has been accepted already. Perhaps it's worth submitting a second "follow-on" puzzle at some point that has harder test cases?

...and now I lost my chance to actually edit what I intended to.

This is getting demotivational.
I can still make edits. Was it cosmetic or functional? If you have a significant cosmetic improvement, I'd recommend at least discussing it.

All cosmetic. (Functionally, this has been good to approve for me for some time, the only reason I hadn't was the editing.)

Oh well, fuck all that, I'm going on holiday.
